result.execSummary:
The defendant Darrin L Malone was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Felony Murder [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime, Repeater], an unclassified felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.03.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant is NOT eligible for Challenge Incarceration and Substance Abuse Programs. Sentence credit of 421 days were granted.
09/12/2016 PER COURT AND DOC, SENTENCE IS CONSECUTIVE, THEREFORE SENTENCE CREDIT ON THIS CASE IS SET AT ZERO.
Consecutive to: Any other sentence

superMiscConds.notes:
Restitution to be determined at future hearing.
08/25/2016 RESTITUTION AMENDED AT HEARING. ACUITY CLAIM #NX0431 $17,318.52 AND CLAIM #NT7676 $20,000.00. ALL RESTITUTION TO BE PAID JOINT AND SEVERAL.
Costs to be paid as a condition of Extended Supervision.

Submit to an AODA assessment, follow through with any treatment, counseling.  No use or possession of alcohol or illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety.

No Contact with the victim's family or any co-actors. Provide DNA Specimen unless previously obtained. Surcharge is imposed. 
  No association with any known drug users or dealers and no contact at any place where illegal drugs are purchased, used, stored, packaged or distributed.
Comply with any mental health/psychological evaluation and treatment deemed appropriate. Work toward or maintain employment and/or school combination. Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by agent. 
  Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided,   immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.
  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

This case is called along with Case #15CF55 (State vs. Jerica Cotton).  Defendant Darrin Malone appears by telephone from Dodge Correctional.  Attorney J Anthony Rosario appears on behalf of Defendant.  Susan L. Opper appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Parties do not contest restitution amount to Whiterock LLC paid by Acuity.  2nd amount paid by Acuity ($18,718.52) is contested.  Case proceeds to testimony.  Jodi E. is sworn-in and testifies.  State's exhibit #1 is marked, offered and received. Cross-examination by Attorney Rosario.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  No further testimony.  Testimony is closed.  State gives closing statements.  Closing statements made by Attorney Rosario.  Closing statements made by Attorney Bihler.  Court finds that part of item #2 is not reasonable but does not know the breakdown of charges on that item.  Court finds that all other amounts are reasonable and allows/orders payment of such restitution by both parties.  Attorney Bihler raises issue of Mr. Malone's ability to pay.  Attorney Rosario also raises issues with ability to pay for Ms. Cotton.   Court orders restitution in amounts ordered by both parties, joint and several.  State requests that parties be ordered to pay a portion of item #2 so that a final amount can be determined today.  Both parties' attorney agree to have item #2 split in half.  Court orders restitution on item #2 in the amount of $1,400.00, for a TOTAL of $17,318.52 to Acuity on claim #NX0431 and $20,000.00 to Acuity on claim #NT7676 - all ordered joint and several.

Defendant Darrin L Malone in court, in custody, with attorney Douglas Michael Bihler.   District Attorney Susan L. Opper appeared for the State of Wisconsin. No corrections to PSI from either party. State gives sentencing recommendations. Atty Bihler makes statements regarding sentencing. Defendant makes Statements. Defendant may be returned forthwith. Defendant to appear by video for Restitution Hearing.The Defendant was sentenced to the following:

COUNT#1:

IMPOSED SENTENCE OF:   

35 YEARS MONTHS IMPRISONMENT (CREDIT - 421 days) 	***CONSECUTIVE TO ANY OTHER SENTENCE***
  -  25 YEARS OF INITIAL CONFINEMENT
  -  10 YEARS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISON 

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISON:  
____AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended;
____Absolute Sobriety;  Random U.A.'s ; 
____No Use or Possession of alcohol or illegal drugs 
____Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
____Work toward or maintain employment and/or combination of schooling 
____No contact with: the victim's family or any co-actors.
____DNA sample to be provided if not yet previously done 
____No association with known drug users or dealers and no contact at any place where illegal drugs are purchased, used, stored, packaged, or distributed.
____Mental Heath / Psychological Evaluation and treatment deemed appropriate
____No possession of any weapons

RESTITUTION: restitution hearing to be set

COSTS:  $268.00 + $250.00 DNA surcharge. (to be paid as a condition of extended supervision)

Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant is not eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

Felony warnings, voting rights and firearms warnings given.  

Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided,   immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.  Restitution hearing scheduled for July 7, 2016 at 01:30 pm.
Filed.

Defendant Darrin L Malone in court, in custody, with Attorney Douglas Michael Bihler.   Susan L. Opper and Brian Juech appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called at 8:37 a.m. for Day 4 of jury trial.   Court performs colloquy with Defendant regarding stipulation filed on February 16, 2016 regarding agreed to facts.  Defendant Darrin Malone states he did sign that stipulation and agrees to facts contained in that stipulation.  State's Exhibit #18A is marked, offered and received.  Attorney Bihler states that Defendant will not be testifying.  Court performs colloquy with Defendant regarding his right to testify.  Defendant states that he does not wish to testify.  Jurors enter courtroom at 8:48 a.m.  Court reads stipulation entered into by parties to the jurors.  State rests.  Jurors exit courtroom at 8:50 a.m.  Attorney Bihler moves for dismissal.  State objects.  Court denies request.  Jurors enter courtroom at 8:53 a.m.  No testimony by the defense. The defense rests.  Jurors exit courtroom at 8:54 a.m.  Jurors enter courtroom at 10:28 a.m.  Court gives jurors jury instructions.  Closing statements made by the state (Attorney Opper).  Closing statements made by Attorney Bihler.  State gives rebuttal arguments/statements.  Court gives additional jury instructions.  Clerk announces 2 alternate jurors.  Remaining 12 jurors exit the courtroom at 12:03 p.m. to begin deliberations.  Jurors enter courtroom at 2:11 p.m.  Court allows jurors to view video (Exhibit #11) from a closer view (jurors stand close to screen).  Jurors go back to jury room at 2:36 p.m. to continue with deliberations.  Juror's reach a verdict at 2:38 p.m..  Juror's enter courtroom at 2:43 p.m.  Court reads the verdict.  The jury finds the Defendant guilty of Count #1.  Court polls the jury.  State moves for judgment on verdict.  Defense moves for acquittal. Court enters judgment on verdict.  Court orders a presentence investigation.  Court sets sentencing date.  Court revokes bail.  DEFENDANT TO BE RETURNED FORTHWITH.
Order for after hours visitation. Signed by Judge Carter on 02/17/16.
filed by the state regarding Dr. Okia's (medical examiner) findings

Defendant Darrin L Malone in court, in custody, with Attorney Douglas Michael Bihler.   Susan L. Opper and Brian Juech appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  State files stipulation as to agreed to facts.  Case called for Day 3 of jury trial at 8:55 a.m. Court goes through issue of Exhibit #14 again with parties after reading transcript from that portion from yesterday's testimony from Det. Carpenter.  State moves to withdraw Exhibit #14.  Jurors enter courtroom at 9:10 a.m.  Court directs jurors that any testimony from Detective Carpenter given yesterday (2/16/16) that cell phone belonged to Defendant, Mr. Malone, is ordered stricken from the record and disregarded by the jurors.  Exhibit #14 is withdrawn and Exhibit #15 is marked.  Detective Michael Carpenter is sworn-in.  State's exhibit #15 is viewed on overhead projector.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Re-direct by Attorney Juech.  Court takes short recess at 9:40 a.m. Jurors enter courtroom at 9:58 a.m.  Kenneth T., in custody, is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Defense Exhibit #16 marked (DVD).  Court takes short break at 10:55 a.m.  Court reconvenes at 11:15 a.m.  State viewed DVD marked as Exhibit #16 on the break and agrees to portions proposed being played for the jury.  Jurors enter courtroom at 11:18 a.m..  Attorney Bihler continues with cross-examination.  Sidebar.  Court breaks for lunch at 11:45 a.m.  Jurors are excused at 11:48 a.m and told to return at 1:15 p.m. for continued testimony.
Court reconvenes at 1:20 p.m.  Jurors enter courtroom at 1:22 p.m.  Attorney Bihler continues with cross-examination of witness Kenneth T.   Re-direct by the state.  Re-cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Court takes recess-jurors exit courtroom at 1:40 p.m. so witness can be returned.  Parties discuss issue of the state playing DVD interview. Court reviews DVD outside of the presence of the jury to see if any objections by the defense.  Court takes short recess.  Court reconvenes at 3:15 p.m.  Defense moves for admission of Exhibits #16 & 17.  Court receives Exhibits #16 & 17.  State moves for admission of Exhibits #14 & 15.  Court receives Exhibits #14 & 15.  Defense Exhibit #16A is marked, offered and received.  Jurors enter courtroom at 3:23 p.m.  Detective Servando Benitez is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  State shows Exhibits #20-23 to witness and moves for admission of those exhibits.  Court receives exhibits #20-23.  Exhibits #20-23 are published to the jury.  State moves for admission of Exhibit #19.  Court receives Exhibit #19 and exhibit 19 is published to the jury.  Exhibit #18 (DVD) is played for the jurors.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Sidebar.  Re-direct by the state.  Court adjourns for the day at 4:40 p.m.  Jurors are excused at 4:40 p.m. and ordered to return at 8:30 a.m. tomorrow (2/18/16) for continuance of trial.  State moves for admission of Exhibit #18.  Court receives Exhibit #18 but requests that the state provide a new DVD of Exhibit #18 with redactions. State will get a redacted version of Exhibit #18.  Court adjourns at 5:00 p.m.

Defendant may meet with his counsel, Attorney Douglas Bihler during non visitation hours on Tuesday, February 16, 2016 for purposes of preparing for his jury trial currently in progress. Signed by Judge Carter on February 16, 2016.

Defendant Darrin L Malone in court, in custody, with Attorney Douglas Michael Bihler.   Susan L. Opper and Brian Juech appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called for Day 2 of jury trial.  Jurors enter courtroom at 8:40 a.m.  State moves to have Exhibits #2, 3 & 4 published to the jury.  Court grants and District Attorney Opper shows state's exhibits #2, 3 & 4 on overhead projector.  Detective Edward Bergin is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  State's exhibit #5 is moved into evidence.  Court receives and it is published to the jury (photo).  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Re-direct by the state.  State's exhibit #8 is offered by the state.  Court will take up issue of admission later, upon Attorney Bihler's request.  John S. is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  No cross-examination by the defense.  Timothy C. is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state. Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Eric G. is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  No cross-examination by the defense.  Court takes short adjournment at 9:53 a.m.  Jurors exit courtroom at 9:54 a.m.  Court reconvenes at 10:12 a.m.  Counsels bring up issue of potential exhibit state wishes to have marked.  Court will allow that exhibit to be marked but will not allow it to be published to the jury.  Jurors enter courtroom at 10:20 a.m.  Det. David Feyen is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  State moves for admission of exhibit #10.  Court receives Exhibit #10.  State moves for admission of Exhibits #7 & 9.  Court receives Exhibits #7 & 9.  State moves for admission of Exhibit #11.  Court receives Exhibit #11.  State moves for admission of Exhibit #6.  Court receives Exhibit #6.  State moves to have Exhibits #6, 7, 9, 10 & 11 published to the jury.  Court grants request.  Sidebar.  Court/jury views DVD (exhibit #10).  Sidebar.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Re-direct by the state.  Det. Daniel Neumann is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Sidebar.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Re-direct by the state.  State moves for admission of exhibit #12.  Court receives exhibit #12.  Court adjourns for lunch at 11:55 a.m.  Court orders jurors to return at 1:20 p.m.   Jurors exit courtroom at 11:57 a.m.  Court adjourns at 12:00 p.m.
Court reconvenes at 1:25 p.m.   All appearances remain the same.  Jurors enter courtroom at 1:27 p.m.  Shakendra T., in custody, is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Sidebar.  State continues with direct examination.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Mandy L. is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.   Court takes short recess to have next witness set up.  Court reconvenes.  Jurors enter courtroom.  Jerica C., in custody, is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  State's exhibit #13 is presented to witness.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Re-direct by the state.  Re-cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Court takes short recess at 3:35 p.m.  Court reconvenes at 3:50 p.m.  State moves for admission of Exhibits #8 & 13.  Court receives exhibits #8 & 13.  Jurors enter courtroom at 3:51 p.m.   Detective Thomas Carr is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.   Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Dtective Michelle Trussoni is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Detective Michael Carpenter is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Sidebar.  State's Exhibit #14 is presented on projector screen.  Sidebar.  Court releases jurors at 4:45 p.m. and orders them to return tomorrow, 2/17/16 at 8:30 a.m. for continuance of jury trial.  Jurors exit courtroom at 4:46 p.m.   Court takes up issue of State's exhibit #14 based on objection by Attorney Bihler.  State questions witness Detective Michael Carpenter regarding exhibit #14.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Attorney Bihler objects to admission of exhibit #14 based on lack of foundation and believes it to be unfairly prejudicial.  State gives comments regarding objection.  Court orders that any testimony regarding phone on exhibit #14 being Mr. Malones' phone, be stricken.  State will redact some of Exhibit #14.  Court adjourns at 5:05 p.m.
2nd Amended Information
Random Listing Report-Voir Dire, Voir Dire List, and Juror's Selection and Peremptory Challenges

Defendant Darrin L Malone in court, in custody, with Attorney Douglas Michael Bihler.   Susan L. Opper and Brian Juech appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called at 8:40 a.m. for 12-person jury trial.  Court addresses issue of charging language with counsel.  Both counsel agree with the court's view on charging language and State to file an amended information.  Parties estimate that trial will be 5 days in length.  Court determines that it will have 2 alternates for jury trial.  Parties will practice 5 peremptory strikes each.  Attorney Bihler files a stipulation regarding  Dr. Okia determining cause of death of victim to be a gunshot wound to the chest.  State files second amended information.  Jurors are called for at 9:00 a.m.   Jurors arrive at 9:30 a.m.  Clerk swears in all potential jurors on voir dire.  Court gives introductions and preliminary instructions.  Court conducts voir dire.  Sidebar.  Allison F. is struck for cause.  Clerk announces next potential juror.  Victor L. is struck for cause.  Clerk announces next potential juror.  Sidebar.  Court takes break.  Potential jurors not in the box go the JAR for a break.  Potential jurors in the box go to jury room for break.  Individual voir dire is conducted on William J.  Individual voir dire is conducted on Therese B.  Individual voir dire is conducted on Laura J.   Therese B. and Laura J. are both struck for cause.  Individual voir dire is conducted on Connie W. .   Clerk has next potential juror brought up from jury assembly room.   Court conducts voir dire of that potential juror.   Clerk has next potential juror brought up from jury assembly room.  Court conducts voir dire of that potential juror.   Anthony M. is struck for cause.  Clerk has next potential juror brought up from jury assembly room.  Court conducts voir dire of that potential juror.  Court takes short break at 11:55 a.m.   Court reconvenes at 12:10 p.m.  All jurors, including entire panel are brough back to courtroom at 12:15 p.m.   State conducts voir dire.  Defense conducts voir dire.  Counsels practice 5 peremptory strikes each.  Clerk announces 14 jurors selected to try the issues (12 person jury plus 2 alternates).  Remaining non-selected jurors and remaining jury pool are released/dismissed at 1:25 p.m..  Clerk gives oath to jurors selected to try the issues.  Court adjourns for lunch at 1:30 p.m. and orders jurors to return at 2:45 p.m.  Court reconvenes at 2:45 p.m.  Court orders sequestration of all witnesses during trial.  All appearances remain the same.  Jurors enter courtroom at 2:50 p.m.  Court gives preliminary instructions to the jurors.  Opening statements made by the state (Brian Juech).  Opening statements made by Attorney Bihler.   Officer Steven Cizinsky is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  No cross-examination.  Ryan P. is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Court takes short recess at 3:35 p.m.  Jurors exit courtroom.  Court reconvenes at 3:42 p.m.  Jurors enter courtroom at 3:45 p.m.  Maqbool M. is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  State's Exhibit #1 presented to witness.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Re-direct by the state.  Re-cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  Detective Caleb Porter is sworn-in and testifies on behalf of the state.  Sidebar.  State continues with direct examination of witness.  Sidebar.  State continues with direct examination.  State's Exhibits #2-4 presented to witness.  Sidebar.  State continues with direct examination of witness.  Cross-examination by Attorney Bihler.  State moves for admission of Exhibits #1-4.  Court receives Exhibits #1-4.  Court adjourns for the evening at 4:50 p.m.  Court directs jurors to return tomorrow (2/16/16) at 8:30 a.m. for continuance of jury trial.  Jurors are excused at 4:52 p.m.  Attorney Bihler requests that the court order the jail to allow him to have direct access to Defendant.  Court grants request.   Court adjourns at 4:55 p.m.
